Event.EventName: Melanoma: A Revolution in Treatments and Research
Event.EventDescription:
Detecting melanoma before it spreads is vital for sun-loving Australians to beat the most deadly form of skin cancer which is responsible for three out of four skin cancer deaths in Australia.
One Perth researcher may have found a way to identify melanoma in its early stages with a quick and relatively painless blood test which could be used to screen at-risk patients and catch the cancer before it spreads.
Find our more about the treatments and current research by attending this public lecture on 20 August 2014.

Event.EventName: Australian Museum Science Festival 2014 Community Day
Event.EventDescription: The Australian Museum Science Festival returns Saturday August 16, this annual family friendly community day celebrates all thing science as part of National Science Week 2014.
Event.EventPayment: See website for details.

Event.EventName: Australian Museum Science Festival 2014: Primary School Week
Event.EventDescription: At the Australian Museum Science Festival primary students attend activities that showcase a range of sciences, including biology, chemistry, physics, maths, engineering, earth and environmental sciences, through an engaged learning experience.
Event.EventPayment: $8 per student, which includes museum entry, expo and gallery visits. Additional workshops range from $4 to $20 and must be pre-booked on-line or over the phone.

Event.EventName: Australian Museum Science Festival 2014: Secondary School Week
Event.EventDescription: At the Australian Museum Science Festival secondary students can attend activities that showcase a range of sciences, through an engaged learning experience.
Event.EventPayment: $8 per student, which includes museum entry, expo and gallery visits. Additional workshops range from $4 to $20 and must be pre-booked on-line or over the phone.

Event.EventDescription: Join Lansdowne's student leaders on an interpretive walk and gain a wider appreciation of Knocklofty’s biodiversity values, heritage and ongoing management issues plus use either face to face or interactive technologies to expand your appreciation of Knocklofty's natural values.
Come along to the Sustainability Learning Centre with your head torches on and walking boots ready to discover all things nocturnal in the bush.

Event.EventName: Sapphire Coast Science Festival Trivia Quiz
Event.EventDescription: Sapphire Coast Science Festival Trivia Quiz: test your knowledge about all sorts of weird and wonderful science in this fun-filled event. Interesting prizes and the chance to have a good night with friends or to meet some new ones. BYO food, drinks and glasses etc. Tables of eight.
Event.EventPayment: $5 per person. Payment method to be confirmed when bookings open later in July.

Event.EventName: Sapphire Coast Science Festival Science Cafe
Event.EventDescription: A Science Café event with science shows by ‘Dr Graham’ and local businesses talking about the science of their food production eg cheese making, fish smoking, chocolate, cheese and wine making, sourdough bread, coffee roasting, chilli products, oyster farming.
Science takes centre stage as National Science Week is launched in Western Australia

Join CoralWatch and local scientists on a guided walk to King Island to discover the beauty and diversity of Moreton Bay's flora and fauna. CoralWatch will provide you with a demonstration and the tools required to monitor coral health. Become a citizen scientist today.

There are many type of marine creatures in Moreton Bay. You can see corals and crustaceans, dolphins and dugongs, turtles and manta rays - right here on your doorstep. Listen to a series of informal talks from scientists to learn more about Moreton Bay and become a citizen scientist for the day.

This is the third of four Stars in the Yarra Ranges events. Mount Burnett Observatory and the ARC Centre for All Sky Astrophysics will bring telescopes, astrophysicists, experiments and live feeds from NASA space missions to the main street of Pakenham. Venue entrance via Gate E on the Healesville Koo Wee Rup Road
Event.EventMoreInfo: Venue entrance via Gate E on the Healesville Koo Wee Rup Road

Kangaroo Island students will work with Seal Bay Conservation Park to host an Australian sea lion Ambassador Exhibition. Student presentations highlighting the role of science in conservation of this endangered species will be on display at various sites across KI throughout National Science Week.

Event.EventName: Awards Day - 2014 DAFF Hermitage Schools Plant Science Competition
Event.EventDescription: The Hermitage Research Facility will again be hosting the annual Awards Day for the DAFF Hermitage Research Facility Schools Plant Science Competition. All students registered for the 2014 competition are welcome to attend.

Event.EventName: Science of the Sea – Oceans of Change: Secondary Schools program
Event.EventDescription: An exciting series of short demonstrations, presentations and displays from leading scientists and science organisations, including CSIRO and the University of Tasmania’s Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies. Tuesday 19 August to Thursday 21 August. Bookings essential. 10:00 am – 11.30 am, or 12:30 pm – 2:00 pm
Event.EventMoreInfo: Tuesday 19 August to Thursday 21 August. Bookings essential. 10:00 am – 11.30 am, or 12:30 pm – 2:00 pm

Event.EventName: Science of the Sea – Oceans of Change at the Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery
Event.EventDescription: This exciting week long program features TMAG, CSIRO, the University of Tasmania’s Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies and other science organisations presenting a fascinating series of displays and demonstrations that will be sure to fire the imagination of visitors. Learn about marine mammals, whale research and DNA, corals of sea mounts, mollusc and their distributions, the Redmap citizen science project, ice dynamics and polar melt, ocean currents and their tracking and much more.

Event.EventName: New Norfolk High School Science Expo
Event.EventDescription: New Norfolk High School is hosting a science expo for primary schools within the Derwent Valley Learning Precinct and the broader community.

Collinsvale Primary School will hold an all day science expo. Students will rotate around a number of science stalls. All students from K - 6 will participate. A practical hands on evening event, inviting families and community members.

Students at Sacred Heart Catholic Primary School will be amazed as the staff at Sacred Heart delight them with the many wonders and features of Science based activities. Students move from classroom to classroom, stopping each time to participate in a brain-bursting science activity.

Classes will be involved in creating and testing water filters to determine the effect of clean water on the production of vegetables:- "Why is clean water important for food production and preparation?" "What happens if water containing harmful elements is used?"

Event.EventName: Future Proofing: Food and natural disasters
Event.EventDescription: Join the Cairns Regional Council's disaster management team in fun ways to learn about what happens to our food, how to make sure we have enough and the right kinds when a natural disaster strikes.

Venue.VenueName: At participating schools at times to suit schools throughout National Science Week

Event.EventName: The Rocky Road to Science – Songs Stories and ‘Speriments
Event.EventDescription: Science sounds so perfect, but researchers regularly wander down the garden path, up the creek and through the mill. Pluto, climate change and purple grass get caught in the cross fire as Phil Dooley shows that facts and truth are only half the story of science.

Come along to the University of Western Australia to hear researching science students deliver a presentation of their research thesis- the only catch is that they have three minutes to do it! This is a great opportunity to come and hear about the future of science research at UWA.
A science expo put on by Year 9/10 students for year 5/6 students.

Join us as we celebrate chemists as local heroes and discover how science saves the day! Join Dr. Alan Yen, United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation, Australia's foremost expert on insects in the human diet, for a stimulating discussion.
Join Professor Barry Brook, Director of Climate Science at the University of Adelaide's Environment Institute, for a brief introduction to climate science.

Event.EventName: Great Apes: Sex, Behaviour and Communication
Event.EventDescription: Join Dr. Carla Litchfield, Australia's foremost expert in primate psychology, for an intimate evening discussing our closest relatives the Great Apes (Chimpanzees, Bonobos, Gorillas and Orangutans).
Join local winemakers and brewers to learn about some of the science behind their craft.

Event.EventName: Be part of linking the Arkaroola Village and future Research Centre
Event.EventDescription: Be part of establishing a permanent remote communications link in the Northern Flinders Ranges. Places are strictly limited, so please contact us 0427 679 796 or the sanctuary on 08 8648 4848 to register your interest. Also note that while the event is free, you will need to provide your own transportation to the sanctuary, lunch and accommodation at the sanctuary. We plan to depart from the Arkaroola Village Admin building at 10am.

Event.EventDescription: Pints. Profs. Science. Join us for a few drinks and a discussion on whether there are there facts we shouldn’t know, technologies we shouldn’t have and lines we shouldn’t cross? In a world of smallpox, chlorofluorocarbons and nuclear weapons, how do we draw the lines of ethical science? And if we trespass too far, can we put the lid back on Pandora’s box?

Daintree Estates, a cocoa growing and chocolate production enterprise located in the Daintree region, will present a talk about their cocoa at the Middle Years assembly. Parents, Carers and Guests are invited to attend.

Daintree Estates, a cocoa growing and chocolate production enterprise located in the Daintree region, will be providing St Andrew’s Catholic College with cocoa beans at various stages of processing.
All 550 students in Middle Years at the College (Yrs 6 to 9) will complete a round robin lesson in the Laboratory with various stations set up to allow students to examine cocoa beans from pods through to fermenting, drying, roasting and cracking.
Each station will explain the stages of production from growing cocoa, processing stages and chocolate production. The lesson will culminate in a small taste of the final chocolate product.
